PM

think this par from Neil Mellor sums up where we are...

PM

The world of central bank communication has changed beyond all recognition since Alan Greenspan delivered his infamous shock to the bond market in 1994 (when, with little warning and no sign of inflation, the Fed started to tighten policy leading to a rout in the Treasury market.) Now, markets are pampered with guidance; but the price paid is that central bank communication has become an (endogenous) variable in the equation of demand and supply, which can assist, but can most certainly inhibit successful monetary management. The Fed has resorted to what has been termed 'meta-guidance' - or guidance about the Fed's own guidance - and it is something that has detracted from what should really matter which is the medium term path of rates and the real economy. Put another way, for some time, the Fed and other central banks have micromanaged market sensitivities that bear no reflection upon the longer-term variables over which monetary policy ostensibly exercises control. And the various shifts in micromanagement themselves have become pivotal to market performance, encouraging a perverse feed-back loop and a softening focus.

Here comes RBC with the headlines.

BE

There were no surprises in FY16 results. The bull will focus on the announced multi-year cost savings war-chest (£100m gross savings by FY19) and support from buybacks
(3% of market cap). But the fact is that FY17E PBT consensus should come down materially again (by ~9%) and the buyback should not be enough to offset another round
of consensus EPS downgrades against an external environment that should remain difficult in FY17. More a er the analyst mee ng star ng at 9:30am UK me.
FY16 results summary - Burberry reported FY16 adjusted profit before tax of £421m, in line with RBC and consensus forecasts (£420m), with retail/wholesale operating
margin of 15.1% (RBC at 15.6% estimate). FY16E dividend of 37p is broadly in line with expectations. Net cash of £660m is also in line with our expectations, assisted by
lower capex.
FY17E guidance – Revised PBT guidance ‘towards the bottom of the consensus range’ which we believe is £375m vs. a current median consensus of £416m (source:
Burberry). This implies consensus FY17E PBT downgrades of ~9% as the luxury trading environment has remained challenging, and underlying operating cost inflation
persists. Component parts of revised guidance include: FX is expected to positively impact £10m lower than previously (£50m vs. £60m), whilst cost savings of £20m
will be offset by £10m investment in retail productivity and the re-introduction of £20m of performance-related pay costs in F17E.
Burberry has confirmed it has intensified actions relating to its productivity and efficiency agenda, and announced a multi-year cost saving program today that is intended
to deliver annualised cost savings of £100m by FY19E. The question mark to us is how much of this cost saving war-chest will be reinvested and how much will flow
through to the bo om line.
Update on cash returns: As expected, Burberry announced a share buy-back program (up to £150m, which is 3% of market cap) and has also adjusted its dividend policy
(FY17 dividend to be at least in line with FY16).
As a reminder, the company had already reported FY16 revenues on 14/04, with retail comparable sales down 5% in the March quarter missing consensus
expectations.

11:18 am
BE

(@Iz: go do a post. Don't waste your time on this shower.)

BE

(No offence, shower.)

BE

Productivity and efficiency agenda in-detail:
Key points from the productivity and efficiency agenda include:
- Productivity agenda: Half of revenue growth to FY19E to come from retail productivity improvements, whilst e-commerce initiatives are expected to deliver
another third. Burberry intends to reduce the weight of outlet stores, and con nue to ra onalize wholesale distribu on where appropriate. The shape of the
cost/benefit will be a cost of £10m in FY17, and then £25m/year for FY18-FY19E through the P&L, in retail, digital and core functions.

- Cost agenda: The company believes it can deliver £20m of cost savings in FY17, however this will be offset by the re-introduction of Performance related pay of
£20m in FY17E. Longer term, the ongoing cost program is expected to deliver annualized cost savings of £100m by FY19E – half of which is to come from
changes to ways of working (organiza onal simplifica on, reducing complexity, etc.)
- Capital returns – Burberry commences a share buy-back program of up to £150m starting in FY17E (3% EPS enhancing), and also announced it is moving to a
progressive dividend policy having reached its payout target (53% in FY16E), and will hold FY17E dividend at least at the FY16 level.
FY17 guidance:
Burberry confirmed the other guidance elements provided on 14/04, namely: (a) low-single digit percentage retail net space contribution, (b) wholesale revenues down
10% in 1H17 and (c) licensing revenue down £20m vs. last year.
The company confirmed PBT guidance towards the bottom of the range (£375), which we estimate could see a consensus estimate reduction of c9% (before EPS accretion
from share buybacks). FX is expected to have a £10m lower benefit, whilst cost savings of £20m in FY17E will be offset by £10m investment in retail productivity agenda,
and re-introduction to PRP of £20m (in addition to the already announced £20m LTIP cost).
Our fundamental view - Underperform
Burberry's equity story is evolving towards a more moderate top-line growth profile one but with greater focus on retail productivity. In our view management continues
to do all the right things for the brand in the long term, but the combination of limited gross margin improvement potential, opex-deleverage and further drop in
Japanese licensing revenue should lead to below sector-average EBIT growth in FY17-18E.

Management indicates that this year’s PBT should move towards the bottom of the consensus range (£370m to £380m vs current average consensus at £415m and SGe at £435m). Main factors: £20m cost cuts (vs SGe at £30m), offset
by £10m reinvestment, £10m lower FX benefit and £20m further bonus reinstatement. Overall, it is a net of at least -£20m for consensus. Moreover, with £20-30m one-off implementation costs, consensus EPS should see a low double-digit downgrade.

BE

Conclusion: no meaningful net cost cuts, immediate opex reinvestment needed, bonus already largely reinstated, material EPS cut
this year, and EPS growth largely hampered next year by more one-off costs (c.£35m), higher savings reinvestment (£25-30m), and potential further bonus reinstatement (£20m). Overall, no EPS recovery before 2019 at the earliest.

Hunan Plantation was developed as a new plantation from 2007 after the Group reached agreement with the Dao County Government of Hunan Province regarding the terms of a proposed 50-year lease of approximately 35 sq.km. of land. The first planting of 427,400 summer orange trees occurred in the year ended 30 June 2011. Hunan Plantation is fully planted and comprises approximately 1.05 million summer orange trees and 750,320 grapefruit trees. As the orange trees are now all 4-5 years old, limited production was anticipated to begin this year, some 2 years behind original expectations. Frosts have again impacted the trees, with temperatures averaging some 5-6 degrees lower than that normally experienced. As a result, any 2016 summer orange harvest is expected to be negligible. The first grapefruit harvest was not anticipated before winter 2017.

BE

Our view: Asian Citrus has announced that it is to shut down Hunan Plantation after an analysis of ways to improve the outlook for production. The Board’s view is that the economic cost of likely expenditure needed to improve yields or replace existing trees outweighs any potential benefits of further investment. There will be associated impairment losses, provisions and terminations costs of approximately RMB1,352m (around £120m). This follows the decision to close its Xinfeng Plantation in December 2015. The Group retains Hepu Plantation and its BPG fruit processing business. It says that a more detailed update will be provided ‘as and when appropriate’. Our recommendation and target price remain Under Review although we intend to revisit these when more information is available. This announcement is clearly disappointing and we note the reference to the Group’s current financial position as a contributory consideration when deciding to close Hunan Plantation.

· Hunan Plantation – Asian Citrus has been developing Hunan Plantation since 2007. It has 1.05m summer orange trees and over 750,000 grapefruit trees. Its first small orange harvest was expected in 2016 – although that was already two years behind plan. The first grapefruit harvest was not expected until 2017. Cold weather, lower than normal by 5-6 degrees, again impacted the trees and any summer harvest this year was expected to be ‘negligible’.

· Concerns and analysis – Given the poor harvest conditions which have persisted, the Board’s concerns over the likelihood that Hunan Plantation could achieve an effective yield and acceptable fruit quality prompted an investigative analysis. Asian Citrus engaged independent experts to ‘conduct an in-depth analysis on the crop progress and conditions in Hunan Plantation’.

· Findings – In light of the impact of the region’s climate on the blossom and infant fruits, the independent experts’ report suggested improved management practices and fertiliser application to increase crop productivity or, alternatively, the replacement of the existing trees with other species ‘more suitable to grow in the region’. Neither option is deemed viable by the Board. The estimated costs of action to increase the yield would be larger than any expected production value while estimated costs of tree replacement ranged from RMB315m to RMB630m (around £28m to £56m).

· Decision to close Hunan Plantation – The Board notes its consideration of the time and costs involved in the two proposals, the uncertainty of the outcome and effectiveness of the proposals and ‘the current financial position of the Group’ in reaching its decision to close Hunan Plantation. It will shut down the plantation and terminate the land lease agreement, with operations ceasing by the end of May 2016.

· Remaining businesses – The update notes that Hepu Plantation is operating as usual and that it is implementing changes designed to improve its operational efficiency and cost competitiveness including the introduction of cooperation agreements with local growers. There is no update on the BPG fruit processing business.

· Valuation – Our estimates remain suspended and our TP and recommendation remain Under Review although we intend to revisit these when more information is made available.

· Risks - Weather and disease remain risks to Asian Citrus with further persistent and heavy rain/wind likely to damage the trees, further reducing yields. The costs of fertilisers and pesticides continue to weigh on the Group and the pricing of its fruit and labour costs are all variables which influence profitability. The knock-on effect of further expenditure and losses on Group cash remains a key risk.

● We initiate coverage of Just Eat with a Buy rating and a price target of
GBp530, offering 30% upside from current levels. Given its clear marketleading
positions, we believe Just Eat has many years of strong top-line
growth, margin development and free cash flow generation to come. We

businesses will materially affect this growth story is flawed, in our view.

● Offline to online migration still has a long way to go: E-commerce

app ordering, which make the telephone an inferior competitor. Just Eat is
the clear leader in all but one of its markets and, thus, the company’s
average 19.6% market penetration implies the migration to digital still
offers substantial opportunities. In fact, even in the UK, Just Eat’s largest
business, 60% of takeaway orders are still made on the telephone.

● Restaurant delivery businesses are not a material threat: There is some
debate as to whether restaurant infrastructure delivery companies (eg
Deliveroo) will materially cannibalise Just Eat’s opportunity. Our analysis
shows this is very unlikely, as the delivery model relies on large basket
sizes and high population density areas. Our data also suggest very
different demographic profiles use Deliveroo compared to Just Eat and
orders in the high-end bracket are a very small proportion of Just Eat’s
total orders.

BE

Valuation compelling: Just Eat’s valuation looks attractive to us, both in
absolute and relative terms. Our DCF suggest a fair value of GBp530,
equating to 30% upside from current levels. Looking at multiples, the
company trades on a 2017 EV/EBITDA and P/E of 16.0x and 24.9x
respectively. This is broadly in line with listed peers but Just Eat offers far
superior earnings growth. In our view, this warrants a premium rating.

11:42 am
BE

Simplistically we struggle to see how any digital led retail platform can lead to higher margins when Amazon is coming into the market and using the retail world's most unbreachable moat, Prime, as it's weapon.

Just ask eBay seven years ago, when eBay marketplace began to slash fee structures for sellers and introduce free listings in the face of the Amazon attack. Just ask the U.S. retail complex in the face of shocking SSS stats in the last two weeks. Many of the clothing retailers and department stores had historically viewed Amazon as a commodity entity and not as a purveyor of fashion - yet such is the pace of Amazon growth that the company is now expected to become the biggest U.S. Clothing retailer by next year. This company uses price as the ultimate destructive, deflationary technology platform to kill incumbency and competition wherever it treads. And the Prime flywheel is genius. Just think ‘Time and Prime’. In a world short time, who else is able to offer a compelling ‘Return on Time’ with friction-less transactions, unbeatable pricing and feeding addiction (one hour delivery, or instant in digital). Amazon doesn’t disclose the number of Prime users but our estimates are for as many as 100 million worldwide (combining data sources from Recode, BGR, Fool.com, Fortune, Business Insider, Statista). That’s 100 million paying prime users who provide $10B (up front) every year to Amazon. So this is the ultimate negative working capital model most companies can only dream of. Competitors can't raise pricing in the face of such a behemoth attacking their defences.

BE

Yep.

BE

ARM has acquired UK-based Apical
(private company), which does imaging and embedded computer vision IP. Both
companies had already been collaborating for 2 years on display products. Apical
was founded in 2002 and employs ~100 people, of which ~80% are in R&D. ARM
notes that Apical’s imaging IP has been cumulatively used in 1.5bn smartphones
and ~300mn other devices (IP cameras, digital still cameras and tablets).

BE

2 strategic reasons for this deal. Imaging is a strategically important
technology (with LT market potential) which also complements ARM’s existing
products around Cortex (CPU) and Mali (GPU). It allows ARM to: i) accelerate
entry into new markets such as connected vehicles, robotics, smart cities,
security, industrial/retail applications and IoT; and ii) extend its offering in existing
markets (smartphones, cameras). Apical has the following products which will
complement ARM's Cortex (CPU) and Mali (Graphics/Video) offerings – i) Spirit:
silicon IP blocks that deliver on-chip computer vision capability by converting raw
sensor data or video into a machine-readable image representation; ii) Assertive
Display: enables screens to adapt to changes in light by overcoming brightness
limitations while reducing power consumption (used in smartphones from
Huawei, LG, Samsung); and iii) Assertive Camera: better camera performance
through high dynamic range, noise reduction and colour management.

11:50 am
BE

BE

Financials of the deal. ARM has acquired Apical for $350mn in cash (£240mn).
Apical had £16.6mn (+30% yoy) of sales in FY15 (Mar year-end) with EBIT of
£8.7mn or 52% margin (+38% yoy). Given strong growth Apical had been seeing
over the last couple of years, if we were to assume 20-25% growth for the next 2
years, this would imply £25mn of sales in FY17, with £14mn of EBIT. This would
be slightly above 2% accretive to ARM on our 2016 estimates (Figure 1). Taking
out the lost interest income of ~£3mn (given £240mn of cash spent on the deal
out of £1bn net cash), this would imply ~2% accretion to ARM's earnings in 2016.
■ TP of 1,175 (~25% upside). ARM shares are trading on PE (ex-cash) of 24x/21x
our 2017/2018 EPS (vs. last 5-yr avg. of 33x/27x and last 10-yr avg. of 28x/23x).
We believe shares can trade at FY3 PE ex-cash of 25x (at a discount to last few
years) plus net cash of 71p per share, which drives our TP of 1,175p.

BE

So, it's a play for the driverless car market and the smart robot stuff.

PM

Been around a long time this Apical

BE

11:53 am
BE

Valuation premium but still below ARM

ARM is acquiring Apical for ~$350m in cash (or ~£245m based on FX rate 1.45) – we note that ARM had net cash of more than £1bn at end-C1Q16. The deal closed 17 May 2016. Based on limited available financial information, we understand Apical had revenue of ~£16.6m and EBIT of ~£9m for FY15 (end-March). Assuming the business has grown 50-75% over the past 12 months with broadly unchanged margin, this roughly implies a multiple of ~8-10x EV/sales and ~16-18x EV/EBIT on LTM basis vs. ARM’s own recent trading (~11-12x EV/sales and ~22-24x EV/EBIT on LTM basis). While Apical might be growing faster, ARM has a more dominant well-entrenched position in smartphones.

Rationale is strategic in nature in our view

Apical provides imaging IP through three products – Assertive Display (display mgmt. core that could sit alongside ARM’s Mali core), Assertive Camera ISP (image signal processor) and Spirit Computer Vision (hardware accelerator for computer vision). Its products are used in more than 1.5bn smartphones (cumulative) including those from Samsung and Huawei. Given the growing importance of imaging in applications such as virtual and augmented reality, we believe the rationale is clearly strategic in nature. We believe that ARM plans to make additional organic investments to enhance its expertise in the area, in addition to the ~100 Apical employees (~80% engineers including~30% having Ph.D. in relevant fields) joining ARM in UK, US and APAC.

Limited earnings accretion in the near term

Like ARM, Apical also operates using an IP licensing and royalties business model and, given Apical locations and headcount profile, we see limited integration risk. We also note that Apical and ARM have collaborated over the past two years. Working with our earlier (see above) assumption of Apical revenue growing 50-75% over the past 12 months, suggests that Apical would have been ~1% accretive to ARM’s normalized EPS on an LTM basis, after adjusting for lower interest income on account of the cash consideration. As such, we see limited earnings accretion in the near term (CY16/CY17), but definitely a more meaningful contribution is necessary in the medium term to justify the move. We are not changing our estimates as part of this note.

We are optimistic on the long-term opportunity

around imaging and, in particular, when it comes to augmented and virtual reality. We recently estimated that augmented reality could represent long-term (2025) upside of 3-9% for ARM’s processor royalties, and the Apical move as such is a step in the right direction.

While wider sector malaise has seen the share price come off recent highs, these numbers demonstrate the discipline that management continues to exert over the business. Our 350p price target values the group on 23x FY17 fd EPS with the rating warranted, in our view, by the unique proposition: 1) well positioned, vertically integrated brands which straddle two growth markets and have plenty of runway for growth; 2) successful formats in a variety of guises and multiple routes to market; 3) strong and consistent cash flows to internally fund growth and an ungeared balance sheet with net cash of £8.9m; 4) no sizeable direct competitors; and 5) a highly experienced management team.

Canaccord upgrade.

BE

Patisserie Holdings' interim EPS was marginally ahead of our forecasts, the new store opening programme is on track and the pipeline is in great shape. The ongoing build up of cash on the balance sheet leaves Patisserie increasingly well placed to step up the rate of new store openings or make bolt-on acquisitions should the right opportunities present themselves. As a consequence, we are increasing our target price to 380p (was 345p) and restore our BUY recommendation (from Hold).

12:00 pm
BE

Interim PBT of £8.4m was £0.2m ahead of our forecasts and £1.4m ahead of last year. The star remains the powerhouse Patisserie Valerie brand helped by the ongoing success of afternoon tea and the growing success of create-a-cake. Smaller brand Druckers also had a good H1 driven by a strong festive period. Management continues to refine the Philpotts offering by shedding lower margin business and the slight dip in turnover was offset by a higher EBIT margin. We have left our full year PBT forecasts unchanged to reflect the cost pressures derived from the introduction of the Living Wage and, to a lesser extent, higher central London rents. This will be offset by an 80bps increase in gross margin as Patisserie exploits its increasing buying power. Patisserie is also testing reactions to a small increase in the price of a cappuccino.

Patisserie has opened twelve new stores and closed one unit (lease expiry) in H1. The openings include a Baker & Spice in Brighton on the last day of the period and it remains on track to open 20 stores. All stores that have opened in the last 18 months are trading well. The Patisserie Valerie brand continues to prove its flexibility with new sites in designer outlets, a motorway service station, shopping centres and three concessions in Debenhams. The second half includes a first store in Northern Ireland in Belfast.

Cash on the balance sheet has increased by £2.8m to £8.9m at H1 despite the commencement of the dividend and an increase in capex. We forecast net cash of £12.5m for FY16E rising to c£30m by FY18E assuming no change to roll-out plans. If one also assumes a debt capacity of 1x EBITDA then PV has a potential war-chest of c.£35m for FY17 rising to c.£45m by FY18. Assuming an immediate 15% return on investment, this could increase earnings by +30%.

BE

Valuation

Patisserie Holdings now trades on a 24.9x PER, 15.2x EV/EBITDA and 4.3% FCF yield for FY16E falling to 20.9x PER, 13.0x EV/EBITDA and 5.1% FCF yield for FY17E. Our new 380p target price is based on 25x underlying 2016E PER plus 35% of a notional upgrade resulting from effective deployment of cash.

Share price performance catalyst

We expect the share price to react positively to these reassuring interims and we expect the company to continue to meet expectations. The next formal newsflow will be prelims which are due in November.
